column6: Commodore Perry's first expedition to Japan arrives in Uraga.
column8: The Perry expedition marks the beginning of diplomatic relations between Japan and the Western powers, and is the initial event of the Bakumatsu (fall of the Shogunate) period.

column6: Five Japanese ports are open to foreign trade following the Harris treaty.
column8: Following the signature of the Harris Treaty the previous year, Japan opens five of its coastal cities to the West: Yokohama, Kobe, Niigata, Hakodate, and Nagasaki (YoKo Ni HaNa). More follow in the next years, such as Edo or Osaka.

column6: Ii Naosuke is killed outside Edo's Sakuradamon.
column8: Ii Naosuke, who signed the Harris treaty with the United States, is shot dead as retaliation for the Ansei Purge.
column9: I read things about Sakuradamon-gai no Hen. I... don't really want to talk about it, it's way too graphic for me.

column6: The American Civil War ends.
column8: The American Civil War, also known in Europe as the "War of Secession", is a major armed conflict of the 19th century. As a non-American, I will abstain from elaborating on this.
column9: They also call it the War between the States... Does it mean it bears similarities with the Japanese Warring States period? I'd have to ask Keine-sensei for this.

column6: The Boshin War ends, marking the end of the Edo period.
column8: The Meiji period began with the Boshin war, a short conflict but with major consequences for Japan. At the end of the war, the victorious new Meiji government would help Japan opening to the West.

column6: The Hokkaido Development Commission (Kaitakushi) is set up.
column8: Japan started colonizing most of Hokkaido (Matsumae in the south was already Japanese) in 1869. This heavily affected the existing Ainu population as their culture became banned on the island (Koseki-hou).

column6: Japan abandons the han system and is partitioned into 306 prefectures.
column8: Under the new Meiji government, daimyos were required to cede their land to the State. This led to the creation of 306 prefectures later merged to form the 47 prefectures we know today.
column9: There's no central government in Gensokyo, so a land partition of this scale wouldn't happen here. Not that there are many humans outside the village to begin with.

column6: Japan switches from the lunisolar calendar to the Gregorian calendar.
column8: Self-explanatory.
column9: So Japan did make the switch to the Western calendar... well, there's many Western dates in bunko and magazines now, so I guess it's kind of logical.

column6: The Satsuma Rebellion in southern Kyushu ends.
column8: The last civil war in Japan ended on September 24, 1877 in Shiroyama (Kagoshima) when what remained of the Satsuma army, led by Saigou Takamori, committed suicide while facing the overwhelming Imperial Japanese Army.

column6: Japanese novelist Higuchi Ichiyou dies.
column8: Higuchi Ichiyou (Meiji 5 - Meiji 29) was a major Japanese writer of the early Meiji era. Even if she died young, her works, such as Takekurabe (1895-96), are still studied in Japanese schools.
column9: She died at 24 and is still remembered today... wait, KEINE-SENSEI!!! YOUR THEOREM IS WRONG AGAIN! I HAVE SOME PROOF RIGHT HERE!

column6: Japanese philosopher Fukuzawa Yukichi dies.
column8: Fukuzawa Yukichi (Tenpou 5, 1835 - Meiji 34) was an influent Japanese philosopher and supporter of the Meiji Restoration policies. His legacy persists today on 10,000 yen bank notes, which are colloquially called "yukichi."
column9: Ten... thousand yen banknotes? That's inflation for you, I guess.

column6: Meiji Restoration figure Ito Hirobumi is killed.
column8: Ito Hirobumi (Tenpou 12, 1841 - Meiji 42) was the first Prime Minister of Japan. He would greatly contribute strengthening the ties between Japan and Western nations. He was assassinated in Harbin Station (modern-day China) by a Korean independentist.

column6: Self-proclaimed clairvoyant Nagao Ikuko dies.
column8: The Senrigan incident, during the late Meiji period (1900-1910s), was an incident that made light on fake paranormal-related activities at the time. Think Sumireko but older and with mass media following her.

column6: A bear attacks the Sankebetsu community in Hokkaido, killing 7 people.
column8: Sankebetsu (Ainu: sanke-pet, downstream-flowing river) was a community in modern Sankei, Tomamae-cho, Hokkaido. It was attacked twice by a bear, killing 7 and injuring 3 others, making it the deadliest bear attack in Japan.
column9: If I had to battle either a mighty Youkai of Darkness and a bear, I would still choose the youkai. People here tend to underestimate the raw power of a bear, mostly because they don't exit the village very often.

column6: Japanese novelist Natsume Souseki dies.
column8: Natsume Souseki (Keiou 3, 1867 - Taisho 5) was a Japanese writer known for reflecting (HA) his views of the Meiji era in his works, such as Botchan (1906), Sashirou (1908) or <s>Hata no</s> Kokoro (1914).

column6: Ainu writer Chiri Yukie, born in Hokkaido, dies.
column8: Chiri Yukie (Meiji 36 - Taisho 11) is probably one of the most known Ainu writers. Her short life was dedicated to the Ainu Shin'youshuu, a collection of oral tales told by the Ainu yukar.
column9: Akyuu, is that you?

column6: Japanese novelist and translator Mori Ougai dies.
column8: Mori Ougai (Bunkyuu 2, 1862 - Taisho 11) was a Japanese writer known notably for Maihime (1890). He translated many foreign authors, such as Daudet, Rousseau, Poe or Tolstoy, among others.

column6: Japanese writer Akutagawa Ryunosuke dies.
column8: Akutaggawa Ryunosuke (Meiji 25 - Showa 2) was a Japanese novelist that gave his name both to a literature prize, as a tribute to his novels (Rashomon in 1915, Kappa in 1927...), and to a certain kappa's theme.
column9: *shows a picture of Akutagawa* Don't know why, but he has a strong cucumber smell. *inhales*

column6: PM Inukai Tsuyoshi is killed during an attempted coup d'état.
column8: On May 15, hence the name Go-Ichigo, Prime Minister Inukai Tsuyoshi is killed in his own house by young military officers. Other government members were also targeted.

column6: Japanese children literature writer Miyazawa Kenji dies.
column8: Miyazawa Kenji (Meiji 29 - Showa 8) was a Japanese writer whose most known novel, Ginga Tetsudou no Yoru (Night on the Galactic Railroad) inspired many other works, such as Galaxy Express 999.

column6: The Toya-maru ferry sinks.
column8: On September 26, the Toya-maru, a ferry on the Seikan Ferry route (Aomori - Hakodate), capsized in the Hakodate Bay during the passage of Typhoon Marie (n°15, later renamed Toya-maru Typhoon), claiming the lives of 1155 people. It is the worst maritime disaster in Japan to this date.
column9: Insert some obvious Sanzu no Kawa trivia.

column6: Ainu linguist Chiri Mashiho, born in Hokkaido, dies.
column8: Chiri Mashiho (Meiji 42 - Showa 36) was a prominent Ainu linguist of Ainu descent, and was also the brother of Chiri Yukie. His considerable works focused on the Ainu origins of Hokkaido place names.
column9: sat-poro-pet, apa-sir, omu-pet, sit-tukari... It's a shame I can't get to see the picturesque Hokkaido that appears in the books. But I heard people from the Mansion went on a trip to see the lavender fields of fura-nu-i...

column6: The folklorist Yanagita Kunio dies.
column8: Yanagita Kunio (Meiji 8 - Showa 37) was a Japanese folklorist and author. Some of his works include Chimei no Kenkyuu (The Study of Place Names) or Tono Monogatari (yes, these Tales of Tono).

column6: An explosion occurs at Mikawa mine, Fukuoka Pref., killing 458 miners.
column8: On November 9, 1963, an explosion caused by sparkles from a runaway mining cart occurs in the Mitsui Miike-Mikawa mine, killing 458 and injuring 839 others (most from carbon monoxide inhalation). It's the most deadly mining accident in Japan since the end of the war.
column9: Is that also one of the reasons why the coal industry isn't very developed in Gensokyo?

column6: The Tokaido Shinkansen, the first high-speed rail line in the world, opens.
column8: Literally meaning "Tokaido New Trunk Line", the Shinkansen was built to reduce congestion on the Tokaido Main Line, which was oversaturated at the time.
column9: They call it the "bullet train." I mean, it's technically true, since you wouldn't want to be in its path when it goes at full speed.

column6: The Sanrizuka Struggle, near modern-day Narita Airport, begins.
column8: Initiated by the Sanrizuka-Shibayama Airport Opposition Alliance, a New Left movement composed mostly of local residents opposed to an international-scaled airport, the struggle, even though it's a taboo in the area, still continues to this day.

column6: The first humans walk on the surface of the Moon.
column8: "I knew I was alone in a way that no earthling has ever been before. I am alone now, truly alone, and absolutely isolated from any known life. I am it." -Michael Collins

column6: The game Pong is released.
column8: Pong is one of the first video games ever made. It also has some reflection mechanics. (hehe see what I just did there?)
column9: Pong?: did you mean Ping?: did you mean Pong?: did you mean Ping?: did you mean Pong?: did you mean...

column6: The United States-controlled prefecture of Okinawa is returned to Japan.
column8: After World War II and Japan's defeat, the United States temporarily occupied Okinawa Prefecture. To this day, they still have military air bases (Kadena, Futenma...) on the various islands of the archipelago.
column9: (tries to speak English with limited success) Guddo Mo'ningu! Mai Ne'mu Izu Books Exist Small Bell! Mai Furendo Millet Field Africa Request! (Phew, even Akor itak was easier than this.)

column6: Japanese Nat. Railways celebrate their last steam locomotive hauled passenger service.
column8: On December 14, 1975, a special "Sayounara SL" service hauled by a C57 steam locomotive arrives at Iwamizawa Station (Hokkaido) after a trip from the coastal city of Muroran.
column9: There might be no bus services in Gensokyo, but who said that there couldn't be rail service?

column6: The British author Agatha Christie dies.
column8: Agatha Chris-Q -I mean Christie is... actually do I really need to present her?
column9: Akyuu is that you again?

column6: The last coal mine in Yubari City, Hokkaido, closes.
column8: Since the late 1960s, a golden era for Japan's mining industry, Yubari City has lost almost 90 % of its population. With only 6,000 inhabitants left, many parts of the city that once were crammed with apartment blocks for miners and their families, are being reclaimed by nature.
column9: I don't think mining would be a viable industry in Gensokyo. That is, except if people are ready to live in cramped bunks far from the village's safety.

column6: Kyoto's municipal streetcar system is dismantled.
column8: Inaugurated in 1895 (Meiji 28), Kyoto's extensive tram network was the first to open in Japan.
column9: A street... car? Don't people in the Outside World usually drive on streets? That doesn't make sense...

column6: Kerninghan and Ritchie publish the first edition of The C Programming Language.
column8: Decades after its publication, The C Programming Language is still regarded by many people as THE reference for anything C-related.
column9: Did you know my powers also apply to programming languages? I could give courses on how to program simple machines in Pascal, ML or Lisp, but today's kids don't seem very interested...

column6: NEC starts production of its PC-98 personal computer.
column8: The PC-9801 is the first generation of PC-98 machines, the most successful Japanese personal computer at the time which is also the target platform for older Touhou games.
column9: Whoa! There's a mini-Reimu moving on the screen! What a strange machine...

column6: French writer Georges Perec dies.
column8: Georges Perec was a French writer known for his unique writing style. His well-known novel La Disparition (The Vanishing, but that misses the point) is a 300-page novel that does not contain the letter E, the most used in French.
column9: That sms quit difficult to achiv in Japans. If you rmovd vry instanc of "shi", you might not b abl to us any vrbs at all. Wll, that might b a challng for Ak- I man, Agatha Chris-Q.

column6: Nintendo releases the NES (Famicom) in Japan.
column8: The Nintendo Entertainment System, known as the Famicom in Japan, is widely regarded as one of the most influential consoles.
column9: Isn't that the console with this game where you can play as an Italian plumber?

column6: Akatani, Shibata City (Niigata Pref.) loses its rail connection.
column8: The Akatani Line was a short unelectrified line that provided rail service to (notably) Ijimino, Yamauchi and Akatani communities. Higashi-akatani Station, the southern end station of the line which also was an industrial hub, is nowadays an empty area.
column9: Y'all know this author from the Outside World, Miyawaki... something? He actually went there, I once read his adventures. Wish I had more of his essays.

column6: 520 people perish in the crash of a Boeing 747 in southern Gunma Prefecture.
column8: The crash of Japan Airlines Flight 123 is also the deadliest involving a single airliner.
column9: So it seems that in the Outside World, humans need these metal terror machines to be able to fly... wait. Keine-sensei, your theorem is wrong again it seems!

column6: The first version of the C family compiler GCC is released.
column8: GCC, a key element of the GNU toolchain, was first written by free software advocate Richard Stallman. As C became the lingua franca for everything Unix-related, GCC grew to become one of the biggest pieces of free software.
column9: Oh yeah, so *proceeds to explain what every SINGLE line of gcc does*. I don't know its utility in Gensokyo, but it sure seems like a lot of fun!

column6: A collision at Paris Gare de Lyon leaves 56 dead.
column8: On June 27, 1988, a brakeless commuter train slams into another one at Paris Gare de Lyon's underground station.
column9: These are scary machines. I'm glad we don't have them in Gensokyo... not that we'd need them anyways.

column6: The Berlin Wall falls.
column8: The 155 km-long wall that separated West- and East-Berlin is torn down. Kosuzu read an article about this.
column9: True!

column6: Nintendo releases the Game Boy in Japan.
column8: For those of you who didn't know it (???), the Game Boy is a legendary handheld console that introduced the concept of interchangeable cartridges. Think a Nintendo Switch with the specs of a Nokia 3310. Sad there's no Touhou on this platform, but I guess it would be very impractical.
column9: Seems like many kids have one today. Apparently they're very fond of that game where you can collect animal-like creatures such as an electric rodent.

column6: Koishi Station, in Sarufutsu Village, closes.
column8: The Tempoku Line (ex-Soya Line) was the first railway line to reach the northern city of Wakkanai in 1922. This remote (but not last) station is not really exciting, except for the fact that it's Koishi.
column9: Please don't make the usual Koishi jokes. The Koishi community isn't dead yet. Wait, that's not what I meant-

column6: Takisato Station, in Ashibetsu City, closes.
column8: Takisato Station was a station on the Nemuro Main Line in Ashibetsu City. The station closed when the line was rerouted, some time before the Takisato Dam opened, submerging the entire valley.

column6: 14 die in a terrorist attack in the Tokyo subway.
column8: Fourteen people are killed by sarin gas inhalation in four packed Eidan (now Tokyo Metro) trains. This terrorist attack was linked to the Aum Shinrikyo cult.
column9: Eidan! Eidan! Tasukete Eidan! (This joke is obsolete as of 2004.)

column6: A M7.3 magnitude earthquake causes chaos in southern Hyogo and Awaji.
column8: At 5:46 AM, on January 17, 1995, the Southern Hyogo 1995 earthquake causes extensive damage in many locations in Hyogo and Osaka prefectures.

column6: Microsoft releases the Windows 95 OS.
column8: Windows 95 was a major overhaul of the previous Microsoft Windows generation, featuring elements that still exist in modern-day Windows versions, such as a taskbar.
column9: Some old magazines in Suzunaan talk about this "Windows" machine, but I've never seen one here...

column6: The Takisato Dam, in central Hokkaido, is put into service.
column8: Takisato was a small village located in Ashibetsu City, Hokkaido, that was submerged when the dam opened. The memories of dozens of villagers are now deep under the lake's surface...
column9: If you reaaaaaally think about it, the Atlantis might just be another Gensokyo, sans the humans.

column6: A law about cattle marking and beef labeling is proposed in Germany.
column8: The name of that law which is too long to fit on the card, but is commonly abbreviated as "RkReÜAÜG", has been nominated by the Association for the German Language for Word of the Year in 1999.
column9: Oh yeah, that famous law about cattle marking and beef labeling supervision duties delegation. In German, they also pronounce it (absolutely butchers the word).

column6: The French Minitel network is shut down.
column8: The Minitel was the name of a French terminal-based computer that allowed connection to the Télétel network, predating the Internet by a few years. It has since become a part of French pop culture, making appearances in various French movies.
column9: I can use my powers on computer programs, but I never knew how to use this machine... even though some people in the village tell me I needed to type in "3615 ULLA" or something like this.

column6: The Passnet magnetic card system used on Tokyo railways is replaced by NFC cards.
column8: Passnet was a magnetic card fare system used by many private railways in the Tokyo region (except JR). It was replaced by the more reliable PASMO card introduced in 2007.
column9: These are some reaaaally fragile telephone cards.

column6: The Nintendo 3DS' online services are terminated.
column8: Since April 8, 2024, it is no longer possible to access online services on the Nintendo 3DS and Wii U.
column9: It's still relatively new. I don't think anyone would consider it a retro console...
